cab.content: APPRECIATION OF THE ATTACHED EASTERN REPORT, No. LITRussia.THERE are signs that a real conflict is nearing between the Bolsheviks and the balance of other parties, but nothing has yet occurred of importance ; the assassination of MM. Shingareff and Kokoshkin and a few street casualties are not true terrorism.Poland.The Polish Lithuanian Social Democratic movement is to be noted; it may be a connecting link between the Russian Revolution and the German proletariat.Turkey.In the appendix are to be found two articles from the " Morning Post" which are nothing more or less than a direct incentive to the Turks to continue the war.Lately it has been obvious that Turkey has been feelino; the strain very severely, and that German influence has consequently suffered. It has been obvious that the Turks have considered whether it would not be best to 1 iok at the Armenian, Arab, and Zionist questions in a new light, -lust at this critical moment the "Morning Post" sees fit t^ come out with articles speaking of the Turks as a " proud and ancient race raging war at the bidding of the northern barbarian, whose purpose as of old is to. destroy a civilisation which he is incapable of understanding and which he hates." It is only to be presumed that the Turkish civilisation is the one which is referred to. Next day the '' Morning Post" speaks of traditional British friendship for Turkey, and idvances the idea that the British people would prefer " a peace to-morrow between Turkey and England" to "the capture of Aleppo." Toe same paper publishes an irticle by Colonel Repington condemning the Palestine and Mesopotamian campaigns, md further describing the shortage of British man-power. The effect of this on the Turk, who is wavering, is to stiffen him up for an indefinite period ; he argues that things ire not so bad as he thought and that he can dismiss any idea of giving in, since not mly are the British incapable of going on with their Eastern campaign, but that three fears of war has reduced them to such a state that treatment of British prisoners, irmenians, and Arabs are no longer matters of consideration.A successful diplomatic offensive against Turkey cannot be expected if such articles ire to be allowed to be published as a regular thing. No pacifist paper or pamphlet :ould do such damage in the East as this.Arabia.The suppression of the Sultan's name in public prayers by the King of Hejaz should )e noted as a definite break between the Hejaz and the Caliphate of the Ottomans.ArmeniaHerewith is circulated a very useful Armenian magazine, future numbers of which vill be supplied with the report.M. Peace negotiations between Russia and Germany will also be dealt with in that report for the future.']RUSSIA.The Constituent Assembly. Mr. Lindley telegraphed on the 18th January [No. 162] that the central committee of Sovyets had published a number of resolutions laying down the role to be played by. the constituent assembly. It must decide that : 1. Russia was a federal republic of workmen, soldiers, and peasants' councils.2. All land, stock, forests, mines, &c, were national property. All Soviet decrees as to control over republics and banks should remain in force. Work must be obligatory for all : workmen and peasants must be armed, and the " possessing classes " entirely disarmed.3. Peace must be obtained by revolutionary methods. There must be a complete break with middle class civilisation. All former government loans must be denounced. No opposition must be made to the power of Sovyets, from which must be excluded all representatives of the middle classes.The assembly must restrict itself to the elaboration of the general principles of socialising society and must leave all details to the local Sovyets of the various states of the federation.On the following day he telegraphed [No. 172] that the constituent assembly opened on the 18th in the presence of about 500 delegates, of whom some two-thirds [898-79] X " B were Social Revolutionaries. Among the absentees were the Cadets and those Miniseveks and Social Revolutionaries who were under arrest. The proceedings were opened by Sverdloff, a prominent Bolshevik member of the Petrograd Soviet, who delivered an address consisting of the Bolshevik declaration given above. The assembly then proceeded to the election of the president. The Bolsheviks nominated Maria Spiridonova and the Social Revolutionaries Chernoff; the latter was elected by 244 votes against 153 with six abstentions. Chernoff in his opening speech expressed the hope that the assembly would endeavour to secure a real democratic international peace by summoning the International Socialist Conference. His statement that B.ussia's efforts towards peace had so far clearly shown the true character of the imperialist central enemies, who agreed to peace in words only in order to cause" dissension between Bussia and her allies, met with general applause. His concluding emphatic statement that the constituent assembly was the supreme authority in B.ussia evoked a loud and prolonged protest from the Bolsheviks. Other speakers followed, whose speeches showed that while the Social Revolutionaries consider the peace question of primary importance, the Bolsheviks insist that approval of their parts of the programme and the recognition of the Soviet's supreme authority should be first matters for business.The election of officers was marked by a considerable display of party feeling. It had been decided that present officers should be only temporary and that the parties should nominate a permanent president on the basis of proportional representation.All the people's commissaries were present except Trotski, who was absent from Petrograd.Telegraphing again on the same day [No. 174], Mr. Lindley said that extra-ordinary precautions had been taken by the Soviet authorities in connection with the opening of the constituent assembly. The Smolny and Tauride palaces were both strongly guarded by Lettish soldiers, sailors, and the Bed Guard, with machine-guns and even field-pieces. Strong detachments of sailors were brought into the town from Helsingfors and Cronstadt. All approaches to the place of meeting of the assembly and Smolny were heavily barricaded and guarded by troops, who in some instances were armed with hand grenades. The strictest orders had been given to suppress, by force if necessary, any armed demonstrations, and on no account to permit any public manifestations near Tauride. The garrison were forbidden to take part in any demonstrations and were ordered to remain in barracks. Workmen were also instructed to remain at (group undecypherable) all day.Notwithstanding this, the Social Revolutionary party organised a peaceful demonstration. Processions consisting of the chief ex-government officials, but with a large proportion of better-educated workmen and even some soldiers, all unarmed, met at various prearranged points of the city. There were several collisions between them and the armed patriots, who in some instances fired on the demonstrators. So far as. is known, there were about 150 casualties, including 25 reported killed. Much blood-shed was undoubtedly avoided by the majority of the processions abandoning all attempts to reach Tauride.Mr. Lindley had learnt that the Bolsheviks, the Left Social Revolutionaries, and the Ukrainian deputies had decided not to attend the assembly any more; and that the commissaries had decided not to permit any more meetings. The hall yesterday was full of armed men and the proceedings appeared to have been finally adjourned as the result of threats.On the 20th January Mr. Lindley telegraphed [No. 183] that the official press had published a resolution unanimously passed by the central executive committee of the workmen, soldiers, and peasants' Sovyet decreeing the dissolution of the constituent assembly on the following grounds : 1. The assembly was non-representative of the political feeling in the country, since the elections had taken place on rolls prepared before October, when the grouping of parties was entirely different, and the authorities were in league and supported by Cadets and similar bourgeois elements.2. The impossibility of working with the right wing of the Social Revolutionaries, who constituted the majority of the assembly and refused to recognise the programme of the true representatives of the people, viz., the Sovyet Government, or to recognise the central executive committee of the Sovyets as the supreme organ of authority, and who, outside the assembly, openly supported the bourgeoisie against the labouring masses in order to prevent the transfer of "land and industrial enterprise to the peasantry and proletariat. " o i 0A decree in accordance with the above would probably be published shortly by the Council of Commissars.Murder of MM. Slimgarefjf and Kohoshhin. Mr. Lindley telegraphed on the 20th January [No. 180] that MM. Shingareff and. Kokoshkin, members of the Provisional Government and of the constituent assembly, had been murdered by Red Guards in a hospital to which they had been removed from the fortress. This was probably the beginning of a reign of terror which would gradually be extended to the whole middle-class population. Mr. Lindley was inclined to think that the dissolution of the constituent assembly would be the high-water mark of Bolshevik power, and that decline might be expected to set in, first in the provinces, and finally in Petrograd. As the Bolsheviks saw power slipping from them, their violence would increase.Treatment of Prisoners of War. Mr. Lindley telegraphed, on the 17th January [No. 15;;] that serious difficulties had arisen between the German and Russian delegates in Petrograd over the treatment to be accorded to officer prisoners of Avar, the Russians demanding the abolition of all differences of treatment. Finally, the Germans asked them categorically whether they recognised The Plague Convention as binding, to which the Russians gave no definite reply.The Bolsheviks and the Roumanian Government. Mr. Lindley telegraphed on the 17th. January [No. 151] the following text oftheultimatumtheRussianGovernmei.it had addressed to the Roumanian Government, which was signed by Lenin, president of Sovyet of people's commissaries ; Krylenko, supreme commander-in-chief; Podvoiski, people's commissioner of war : The chief of the forty-ninth reA-olutionary division has handed us a protest respecting the behaviour of the Roumanian authorities. The Roumanian authorities not only do not recognise the elective principle existent in the Russian army, but are unwilling to enter into any agreement with the elective chiefs of the repre-sentatiye committees, and are also seizing the forage reserves of our troops, owing to which the horses of the forty-ninth division are without fodder. Movements of regiments are being held up by armed force. One regiment, the hundred and ninety-fourth Troitsko Sergiefski regiment, has been surrounded by Roumanians, transport supplies cut off, and the regiment disarmed and conducted to the rear. The Roumanian authorities also arrested the elected committee of the hundred and ninety-fifth regiment and the Austrian officers invited as guests to the staff of the regiment. The council of the people's commissaries demands of the Roumanian Government the release of those arrested, the punishment of those who effected the arrest, and of the Roumanian authorities Avho have been guilty of irregular and illegal conduct; also a guarantee against the repetition of such behaviour.We shall regard non-receipt of reply to this demand within twenty-four hours as a, fresh rupture, and shall then take most decisive military measures.The Roumanian Legation. Mr. Lindley telegraphed on the 17th January that the Roumanian minister and his staff had been liberated on the 15th January.POLAND.Resolutions of the Polish-Lithuanian Social Democratic Party. Sir E. Howard telegraphed on the 19th January [No. 148] that according to the "Social Demo-kraten " resolutions to the following effect were passed by the Polish Lithuanian Social Democratic Party at the conference held recently at Warsaw: The so-called independence of Poland is entirely contrary to the will of the masses of the Polish people, which will is more and more making itself felt. Poland should become an autonomous part of the Russian republic ; and it was to the interest of the Polish working classes to unite, as a revolutionary class, Avith the Russian proletariat during the present proletariat dictatorship in Russia. Further the Polish Lithuanian. Social Demociatic Party Avould continue to disclose the true character of the so-called Democratic Polish Government; that is to say violent reaction, in certain Polish clerical and junker circles, against the Russian reA-olution, and brutal annexation on the part of German imperialism. GREECE.Greece and an Allied Conference. Lord Grairvdle telegraphed on the 15th January [No. 48] that the Greek Government had instructed its ministers in London and Paris to claim that the representatives of the smaller allies should be heard in any conference which might meet to discuss war aims, even if t\yQj could not take part in it. The objects in view were of course (1) recognition of the claims of Greece; (2) the obtaining of a guarantee that Eastern Macedonia should be restored; and (3) if possible, inducing some consideration for the Greek population of Thrace and Asia Minor. The fact that in the declarations of all allied speakers the question of the Greek population of Turkey (instead of being placed on the same footing as Jews, Arabs, and Armenians) was excluded was being dwelt on more and more by the press.The Ministry. Lord Granville telegraphed on the 17th January [No. 58] that M. Repoulis (who was, he had been informed, regarded by M. Venizelos as one of his most valuable advisers) had resigned. He had been appointed minister without office and vice-president of the council. M. Repoulis was spoken of as being scrupulously honest, but too weak in his treatment of deputies who asked for favours. M. Ractivan had been appointed minister of the interior ; in a former Venizelos Government he was minister of justice.The King's Household. On the same day Lord Granville also telegraphed [No. 59] that the removal of all the King's household had been announced; they were accused of working against the present regime. It was stated that M. Gryparis, late minister at Vienna and now head of the King's political cabinet, was to be chamberlain, and M. Melas, late secretary of the Greek legation in London, master of ceremonies.TURKEY.Alleged Agreement between the Sultan and the German Emperor. -Sir IT. Rumbold telegraphed on the 17th January [No. 58] that he had heard from a reliable source that whilst the German Emperor was in Constantinople an agreement was entered into between him and the Sultan, in which the following were the principal points : Germany, Austro-Hungary, and Bulgaria were to do their best to recover Turkey's occupied provinces for her ; Arabia and Armenia were to be disposed of as seemed best to the Turkish Government; Turkey was to retain all her pre-war territories, and to remain an absolutely free state, the Sultan retaining the rank of Caliph.PALESTINE.General Situation. On the 21st January Sir R. Wingate transmitted [No. 151] a telegram from General Clayton on the situation in Palestine. General Clayton reported a continued improvement in the economic situation. Cultivation was proceeding satisfactorily and the harvest should be good ; every possible effort to assist the people in this direction was being made, and measures had been taken to ensure a sufficiency of food until the harvest. There was no appreciable change in the political situation. Owing to a long standing distrust of paper and the shortage of silver, the currency question was still difficult; but as soon as transport difficulties were overcome there would be a reopening of trade and that would be the remedy.The Jewish Colony. In the same telegram General Clayton said that the present population of the Jewish agricultural colonies was approximately 7,000, in occupied territory, whilst the urban elements were estimated at 2,400 in Jaffa and Tel Aviv. In the autumn of 1917 a good many young men were arrested and sent to Damascus; but the man power of the colony had not suffered to the same extent as the Arab population from the requisitions for military service. The most urgent matters at present was the import of rice, petroleum, and medicines, and the revival of oranges, wine, and almonds. Every assistance was being given so far as the transport situation permitted.Abyssinians in Jerusalem. Sir R. Wingate telegraphed on the 22nd January [No. 152] saying that he felt confident of our gaining considerable political advantage at Adis Abeba if we showed attention to the needs of the Abyssinian colony in Jerusalem in view of the very great interest of Abyssinians in that city. He strongly recommended that the local military authorities should be permitted to sjjend up to 250Z. for the relief of destitute' Armenians ; this to be in addition to the arrangements already made for supplying them with food.ARABIA.Hejaz.Suppcssion of Sultans Name in Friday Prayers. Sir R. Wingate telegraphed on the 17th January [No."l2S] that the name of the Sultan of Turkey would no longer be mentioned in the Friday prayers in the Hejaz moscpies. This had been done by order of King Hussein, whose action was officially noticed in " Al Kibla," the Mecca newspaper; it was there explained that the order had been put out because the Moslems of Turkey had not repudiated the desecration of Medina perpetrated by the Unionists.King Hussein and Ibn Saud. Telegraphing to Sir P. Cox on the 11th and 14th January, Mr. Philby rejiorted that in all matters relating to Ibn Saud King Hussein, though unable to substantiate a single grievance or accusation, was utterly impossible and unreasonable. It appeared to Mr. Philby that the King's policy was based on a determination to prevent any Arab chieftain from sharing in Britain's bounty, lest thereby his own difficulties should be increased ; difficulties, that is, in the way of bis establishing himself as king of all Arab countries. Emir Abdulla [who had accused Ibn Saud of discourtesy in not replying properly to a letter he, Abdulla, had written] when challenged to produce his letter and Ibn Saud's reply, was unable to do so. Mr. Philby was not inclined to attach much importance to the alleged correspondance. As an instance of Abdulla's attitude, Mr. Philby mentioned that he opened'the conversa-tion by calling Saud the son of a clog, and declaring that he was true to the treacherous stock from which he had sprung : in regard to which Mr. Philby said that Ibn Saud, on his part, said practically the same thing in regard to the Hejaz family, whilst his remarks on the failure to capture Medina resembled those of Abdulla in regard to Ibn Saud's inaction in regard to Hail. Mr. Philby added that he became more and more convinced that there was danger of serious trouble in Arabia if the mutual campaign of calumny, amidst such inflammable material, was allowed to continue indefinitely for our benefit. The only solution he could see was helping Ibn Saud to capture Hail, whilst pressing King Hussein to capture Medina; and, when the Turks had thus been driven from Arabia, an ambassador should be deputed to settle the boundary of our allies, and so put an end to these political differences.Nejd.Ibn Saud and Ibn Rashid. The Viceroy telegraphed on the 5th January saying that the retention of Ibn Rashid would assist in the maintenance of the balance of power between Ibn Saud and King Hussein, whilst his elimination from Arab politics might be an embarrassment to us ; he was not in a position to do us much harm, and he provided occupation for Ibn Saud. The Indian Government fully realised our obligations to the latter, and had no wish to act unfairly ; but it did wish to avoid the possibility of his being put in a position to upset the equilibrium of Arabia, and therefore recommended that he should be kept in play by presents of money. Assistance in arms and money, however, should be given ve^ sparingly.To this the India Office replied on the 14th January saying that His Majesty?s Government agreed that it would suffice for the present to dole out money to Ibn Saud in such quantities as Sir P. Cox might think right, it being undesirable to give him military assistance on the scale proposed. Sir P. Cox should be instructed accordingly. It was most undesirable that the Arabs should suspect us of being lukewarm in our support of Ibn Saud against Ibn Rashid ; and Sir P. Cox would recognise the need for discretion in carrying out his instructions.Hadxiamaut.Proposed Treaty between Sultan Mokalla and the Kathiri Chiefs. Sir R. Wingate telegraphed on the 16th January [No. 116] that Sultan Mokalla wished to makepeace with the Kathiri chiefs on certain terms to which he, Sir R. Wingate, could see no objection, though he doubted their being accepted by the Kathiri; he doubted, indeed, whether there could be any real settlement unless they were granted access to the seaboard. The terms proposed were as follows : the Sultans of the Kathiri to acknowledgv, [898-79] C the suzerainty of Mokalla, subject to which and the acceptance of British protection there would be local autonomy ; future disputes to be referred for settlement to the resident at Aden ; the Kathiri to address communications to Aden through Mokalla. and to be precluded from correspondence, with foreign Powers.PERSIA.Neiv Cabinet. Sir C. Marling telegraphed on the 19th and .21st January [Nos. 51 and 52j that a cabinet had been formed by Mustaufi-ul-Mamalek. Among the other ministers were Mushaver-ul-Mamalek, Mukhbar Sultaneh, the latter's brother Mukhbar Mulk, Sardar Assad, Moin-ul-Vezareh, and Motamin-ul-Mulk, who had the ministries of foreign affairs, justice, finance, posts ancl telegraphs, public works, and education respectively.In a previous telegram [No. 41] sent on the 16th January, Sir C. Marling had said that if Mustaufi-ul-Mamalek were successful in forming a cabinet, the combination would be so feeble and timid that its only use to us would be its affording an occasion for a declaration of our friendliness, and of our readiness to come to terms on questions in dispute. Political circles were agreed that such a cabinet could not last.General Situation. Sir C. Marling telegraphed to Sir P. Cox on the 19th January in regard to the general situation in Persia. The Shah, he said, had no consistent attitude : he was in a state of abject fear and was remitting his savings to Europe. Unless the pro-German extremists got into office, no cabinet would go far in active bostilhy or active friendliness; Persians were always ready to go with the side that showed strength but were too timid to commit themselves deeply. When the Turkish and German ministers should have returned with a large number of agents, there would be a danger that they might succeed in bringing about a rupture of relations between Persia and ourselves by working with the reckless extremists : to guard against this an endeavour was being made to render that coup impossible by the creation of a feeling in the moderate democrats in favour of good relations with us.German and Turkish Ministers. Sir C. Marling telegraphed on the 17th Januaiw [Nos. 45 and 46] that information had been received of the impending arrival of the German and Turkish ministers. General de Candolle at Novo Cherkask and the consul at Rostov had been requested to take all possible steps to prevent them passing through the Caucasus ; but the military attache at Tiflis thought it doubtful whether effective measures could be taken at Baku, which was almost entirely Maximalist.The Christians of Urumia. Sir C. Marling telegraphed on the 17th January [No. 43] that the governor-general had sent 300 Karadagh horsemen to Urumia to protect the lives ancl property of Christians; it was however generally believed that these tribesmen would be the first to loot and murder should the opportunity arise,, a belief shared by Sir C. Marling himself. The Persian Cossacks were recruited from the Avorst characters in the town and their commandant was said to be inefficient; so they toe were unreliable. It seemed impossible for the Persian authorities to take really effective measures ; that the more that they have to deal, in a district Avhere they haA7e very little prestige or authority, with Avild Moslems Avho hate Christians, as well as with some thousands of lawdess Christians from over the frontier whose behaviour has not always been too good.LATEST INTELLIGENCE.BUSSIA.The Bolsheviks and the autonomous Russian States. Mr. Lindiey .telegraphed [No. 179] on the 20th January pointing out that the autonomous states in course of formation were based on the principles of our nationality and of our civilisation. There could, therefore, be no working, with the Bolshevists, who, in every district in which, they were not suppressed, Avere not only preaching but enforcing by violence their doctrines; i.e., the replacement of national feeling by class feeling, of national Avar by class war. of our civilisation by a new order. The Bolsheviks would never agree not to interfere with the internal affairs of the autonomous states; interference of that kind was the essence of their policy. APPENDIX.The following leading article appeared in the " Morning Post " of Tuesday, the 22nd January : The Position of Turkey.The loss of the " Goeben " and " Breslau " (or in Turkish " Sultan Selim " and " Medilli") may serve to remind the Germans of what their historical learning must have suggested to them, that if the British Navy misses one opportunity it is very unlikely to miss the next. With profound regret and sincere recognition of their services, the country receives at the same time the news of the losses of the two British vessels, His Majesty's ship " Raglan," Commander Viscount Broonie, ancl " M 28," Lieutenant-Commander Donald P. Macgregor. In so far as the ships ^done are concerned the exchange of two monitors for the two German vessels is well worth while. For the " Goeben " and the " Breslau" were Turkish only in name. Officered and no doubt. largely manned by Germans, they were employed in the Black Sea as the symbol and instrument of the German hegemony over the Ottoman Empire. Incidentally they afford a singular instance of the use of sea-power, in that a couple of ships, operating upon an inland sea, were able to dominate the capital of a Power in alliance with the dominating Power. At the same time thev were a menace though before the revolution not a serious menace to the Russian Black Sea vessels of war and merchant ships. We cannot but believe that the Turks are exceedingly glad to be rid for ever of the " Goeben " and the " Breslau." Their elimination removes an integral part of the German power from Constantinople, and there is no chance of other German vessels arriving to take their place. The failure of German and Austrian naval power in the Mediterranean, submarine depredations excepted, is now complete. In respect of the eastern ambitions of Germanj-, the Mediterranean remains the key of the strategic position, and it is held by the allies. Sea power is the periphery of the whole theatre of war; and although Germany has the advantage of interior lines on land, whenever she touches the periphery she is checked. Moreover on the sea the allies hold the interior position, for they hold all ports and bases of supply, in default of which a hostile fleet, once it ventures out of reach of its own ports, themselves subject to distant blockade, is helpless.The '; Goeben " and the " breslau," broadly speaking, brought Turkey into the war. They have now disappeared, and with them is lopped off a limb of German aggression. The alliance of the Ottoman Empire with Germany was and is an anomaly. The advantage to be gained by Germany was plain enough. Turkey was to serve as the Mittel-Europa road to the East, the washpot of Germany, over which she cast out her shoe. The Turk is far too astute a politician not to recognise that alliance with Germany inevitably involves the political and economical subservience of thePALESTINE.The Administration of Palestine. Mr. Balfour telegraphed [No. 105] to Sir H. Wingate on th*s 23rd January informing him that a complete division between the two flkdministrations of Egypt and Palestine had been decided upon. General Allenby is in supreme control of military operations in the Palestine theatre, and General Clayton will be his chief political officer; the latter will receive his instructions direct from the Foreign Office in regard to matters purely affecting policy. The Arab bureau in Cairo would remain under the control of Sir B. Wingate, but a separate branch, to be controlled, by General Clayton, should be established in Palestine.Sir R. Wingate would retain his present position in regard to Hejaz ; but it had been suggested that there should be a new line of demarcation between the theatre under his control and that under General Allenby, ancl that this line should pass through Tebuk leaving Akaba in the latter sphere.The Turks and the Latin Patriarch. General Clayton telegraphed [C. 97] on the 22nd January saying that Monsignor Ricardo, patriarchal vicar, an Italian subject, had been deported by force on the 24th November, being ill at the time; he reached Damascus on the 2nd December, and died on arrival from the fatigue of travelling. The patriarch himself, Monsignor Camise, also an Italian subject, left Jerusalem for Abou Ghosh, for change of air, but was brought back and deported to Nazareth. oPower thus allied. But the Ottoman Empire no doubt received the assurance of Germany that she would so deal with Russia that Turkey would be freed from the pressure of the great empire on the north and east. Imperial Russia demanded, and received, the assurance from the allies that she should on certain conditions occupy Constantinople as her part in the settlement contingent upon the victory of the allies.^ In respect of that bargain it may be said that the internationalisation of the Dardanelles in itself is a measure which would be highly conducive to the peace of the world. The agreement concluded with Russia by the rest of the allies was forced upon them by the adhesion of Turkey to Germany. But it need not now be discussed, inasmuch as the Prime Minister has recently stated that the allies no longer contemplate the cession by the Ottoman Empire of its capital. The Government of Russia, in so far as a government exists, has expressly repudiated internal ional agreements concluded before the revolution; and, indeed, should Russia make a separate peace with the Central Powers these become null and void. Russia, in agreeing to an armistice, has already virtually broken the Pact of London, by which each of the allies was bound not to make peace without the consent of the others. And, so far as Russian international jsolicy is concerned, it may at present be described as consisting in the maxim of the " self-determination of peoples," the Russian people being apparently excepted. But the Turks are clearly included in the formula.The Ottoman Empire, by a strange sequence of events, has now been relieved from one great danger, certainly for some time to come, and in the weakening of the German grip, in our view at least, Turkey has been partly delivered from an even more sinister fate. For we can conceive of no worse destiny than submission to German domination. Should Germany obtain either peace on her own terms or victory, her future rule of the Ottoman Empire is assured. On the other side of the account is the restoration to Turkey of her European empire. But it would be an empire over which the German Emperor would rule. Yet there is no other Bower which proposes to hold Turkey in tutelage. In these circumstances it is strange enough that Turkey should be fighting on the side of the oppressor against a Power to which Turkey has owed so much in the past. A proud ancl an ancient race are found waging war at the bidding of the northern barbarian, whose purpose, as of old, is to destroy a civilisation which he is incapable of understanding and which he hates. It has long been the. declared ambition of the German Emperor to impose the Prussian tyranny upon the Moslem. But we in this country cannot but remember that the Mohammedans make up a great part of the British Empire, in which they dwell secure and free.On the following day, in a leading article headed " The Mad Gyroscope," this passage was found : ;Nor wall they [the army and public] object because Sir William Bobertson attacked the German army in Belgium instead of striking in the sweltering heat of last July at the " vital junction of Muslimie." For the British people, when all is said, have no quarrel with the Turks. They had always been good friends until Germany came between, and a peace to-morrow between Turkey and England would be far more popular than an advance on Muslimie or the capture of Aleppo. If a British general thinks it more in the interest of England and a more practical operation to attack Germans in Belgium than Turks in Asia Minor, the British nation, if we know anything about it, will cordially agree.
